componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes the MetroPCS Communications First Quarter 2010 Conference Call. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect and have a pleasant day.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Sonia and I will be your conference operator for today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the First Quarter 2010 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Terreri, you may begin your conference
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Sonia and I will be your conference operator for today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the First Quarter 2010 Financial Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Terreri, you may begin your conference.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sonia. And good morning, everyone. Welcome to our First Quarter 2010 Conference Call. The speakers with me this morning are Roger Linquist, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Tom Keys, our Chief Operating Officer; and Braxton
componenttext:
Thank you, Sonia. And good morning, everyone. Welcome to our First Quarter 2010 Conference Call. The speakers with me this morning are Roger Linquist, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Tom Keys, our Chief Operating Officer; and Braxton Carter, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
The format for today's call is as follows. First, Tom will provide an update on a number of operational results and initiatives, then Braxton will review the financial highlights of the first quarter 2010 and finally Roger will provide an overview of our business followed by a question-and-answer session.
During today's call we will refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures. We have reconciled these historical non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures in our earnings release, which is available in the Investor Relations section of our Web site at www.metropcs.com under the Investor Relations tab. Also this quarter, supplemental slides are available for download and printing on our Investor Relations Web site. Please note, however, management will not refer to these slides in their prepared comments.
We prepared these slides as a means to show quarterly highlights, graph historical trends in many of our metrics, as well as compare our industry leading, low-cost structure to other major wireless providers. These slides may contain forward-looking statements and may refer to publicly-available information.
Before I turn the call over to Tom, I want to remind you that certain information that we will discuss in this conference call may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of federal securities laws. Words such as believes, anticipates, expects, intends, plans, should, good, would, view, estimates, projects and other similar expressions typically identify forward-looking statements. Forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to, statements we make regarding our future plans, our prospects for success in the highly competitive wireless environment, the effectiveness of our marketing efforts, the seasonality of our growth, the improvement in the economy, forecast when our NOLs will be used, what our acquisition of C9 Wireless interest in Royal Street Commission will close, the dynamics of the wireless marketplace, the value customers ascribe to our service, the rollout and launch of our 4G network and services, the future costs of LTE and future cost advantages of LTE and the impact of Wireless for All and its acceptance by consumers, our objectives, strategies, goals, future events, revenues and performance or other information that is not historical. 
Forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results or the timing of events to differ materially from those made in the forward-looking statements, including but not limited to, competitive responses, change in competitive dynamics, the success of our marketing and cost control initiatives, our ability to launch our LTE network, our ability to efficiently manage our spectrum use, changes in tax and regulatory fees or the continued success of our indirect channels to distribution. We cannot assure you that the forward-looking statements discussed on this conference call will be attained. Our forward-looking statements also are subject to general economic conditions, financial, competitive, business, political, regulatory and other factors that are beyond our control, including but not limited to, the risk factors described in our earnings release, which is available on our Web site and our annual report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and periodic reports on Form 8-K, including our quarterly report on Form 10-Q filed for the quarter, March 31, 2010, to be filed by Monday, May 10 with the SEC and other filings with the SEC, all of which can be obtained free of charge from the SEC at www.SEC.gov or from our Web site or directly from the company by contacting the Investor Relations department. We encourage you to review them.
We would also like to remind you that the results for the first quarter may not be reflective of results for any subsequent period. Also I'd like to remind everyone effective January 1, 2010, we now aggregate our 13 operating segments into one reportable segment. For anyone listening to a taped or webcast replay or reviewing a written transcript of today's call, please note that all information presented is current only as of May 6, 2010, and should be considered valid only as of May 6, 2010, regardless of the date reviewed, read or replayed. MetroPCS disclaims any intention or obligation to revise or update any forward-looking statements whether as a result of new information, future events or developments or otherwise except as required by law. The company does not plan to update or reaffirm guidance except through formal, public disclosure pursuant to Regulation FD. Certain terms used in today's calls are registered trademarks of MetroPCS. 
I hope by now you've had a chance to review our earnings release issued this morning with the financial and operational results for the first quarter of 2010. Again, I encourage everyone to read our earnings release in conjunction with the information discussed in this call, along with our previous SEC filings. We intend to file our quarterly report on Form 10-Q for the period ended March 31, 2010, with the SEC by Monday, May 10.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chief Operating Officer, Tom Keys.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Keith. And good morning, everyone. I'd like to begin today with the discussion of our first quarter operational results. After launching our Wireless for All campaign in January, MetroPCS is proud to report record net subscriber additions and sign
componenttext:
Thanks, Keith. And good morning, everyone. I'd like to begin today with the discussion of our first quarter operational results. After launching our Wireless for All campaign in January, MetroPCS is proud to report record net subscriber additions and significantly lower churn. These operational achievements were driven by the success of our Wireless for All campaign. In the first quarter of 2010, we recorded nearly $1.5 million gross additions, 692,000 net subscriber additions and reduced year-over-year churn by 130 basis points to 3.7%.
As you may your recall, the main premises behind our Wireless for All go-to-market strategy included no contract segment leadership, simplicity and predictability for consumers, Wireless for All traction and service plans stability. While we are always mindful of economic realities and the competitive pressures that exist in our markets, we are pleased with our plan mix in the first quarter, and believe that our current price points provide outstanding value to the consumer. Maintaining consistent and predictable market pricing is important to the continuation of the success we have seen with the implementation of our Wireless for All campaign.
With regards to our no contract unlimited segment leadership, in our markets we believe we had more retail net additions than any other retail facilities-based wireless provider during the quarter. This was a great customer response and a vote of confidence for our new plans. We leveraged our best-of-class cost structure to absorb the taxes and regulatory fees into our new plans, and at the same time effectively managed our customer acquisition costs. 
Gross additions in the quarter were driven by sales of the Samsung Freeform. This QWERTY handset was fastest to achieve 1 million unit sales in our history. The Freeform features a QWERTY keyboard and an affordable retail price point of $79. Smartphones and QWERTY handsets resonate well with our subscribers. Going forward, we plan to continue to introduce additional smartphones and QWERTY handsets.
For the quarter, MetroPCS was ranked number one in overall share position when compared to all of our competitors in the same markets by an independent third party. Additionally, for the entire quarter our internal porting data shows that for each month of the quarter ports in exceeded ports out to MetroPCS verse every contract wireless provider. The shift to UNC, unlimited no contract service, is in full gear. Our belief is that this space is growing and that the market has room for multiple players that offer value and deliver quality to the consumer.
Our new advertising campaign, Tech and Talk, that surrounds our Wireless for All offer with the educational message that you can purchase an unlimited, talk, text and web service plan for $40 period has been well received. In the first quarter, we spent an incremental $26 million in promotional activities, and we believe this messaging helped to educate the public on our new marketing platform and we believe generated door swings. Going forward, we plan to continue to develop Ranjit and Chad and their Tech and Talks campaign, as we highlight the elements of our Wireless for All service platform. Evidenced by this quarter's operational results, we believe it's clear that the simplicity and predictability of our new tax-inclusive service plans resonated well with the consumer. Now that the customer is paying for the first month of service at the time of the handset purchase and paying less for that handset, we have reduced first month bill shock for our subscribers. With Wireless for All, we have recaptured our market leadership position. The customer perception of lower-cost phones is a key factor in attracting new subscribers.
One of the benefits of this approach is that the customer is generally out of pocket the same amount of cash when they leave the store. Our indirect distribution channel dealers are now compensated on the service plans they sell versus selling handsets. This transition has enabled our sales people to engage with the customer and better match their needs with a specific service plan. Now the true value of our $40, $45, $50 and $60 rate plans will be more apparent. This skill set will be even more important to MetroPCS as you move into the 4G era.  As we get into the seasonally slower summer months, we would expect to see lower net subscriber additions and a seasonal increase in churn. However, we believe the triple play inside Wireless for All, tax-inclusive rate plans, lower cost handsets and payment for the first month of service should continue to have a positive impact going into the summer months.
Churn in the first quarter, which came in at 3.7% represents a significant reduction from the first quarter of 2009. On previous calls I've discussed the idea that managing churn is an ongoing focus for the company. With our Wireless for All campaign, I believe we increased overall customer satisfaction, created programs that promote positive distribution and improved customer behaviors that helped to lower churn for the quarter. We believe that the majority of the reduction in churn leads to a decline in false churn as we no longer offer the first month of service for free.
Wireless for All as a campaign and a pricing platform is still in its infancy. Our goal is to continue to gain traction with our marketing platform while we stabilize pricing at current levels. Distribution as well as consumers really found the elements of this unlimited, no contract tax-inclusive offering satisfying and easy to understand. The success of Wireless for All is evidenced by the results of our recent survey work on new customer acquisition. Our internal survey data showed us that roughly 1/3 of those surveyed transitioned from contracted service. Over one quarter came from prepaid plans, about 1/5 were previous MetroPCS customers that came back and purchased a new handset and the balance for new to wireless.
With the rollout of Wireless for All, we grew by nearly 700,000 net subscriber additions in the quarter and have a total of over 7.3 million subscribers. As we look forward, we believe that the more $45 and higher rate plans we sell, the more stable our ARPU will remain. In fact, during the month of March, four out of five gross additions were in the $45 or higher plan. We have heard and read everyone's comments as they relate to competition and potential pricing pressures. The industry continues to be a competitive one, but we believe we are well positioned with Wireless for All now and in the future. While it's difficult to predict the future, we believe we see signs of pricing stability in the industry. The simplicity of our tax-inclusive offerings makes it easy for customers to know exactly what they are purchasing. We have redefined predictability by making the plans easier to budget for. 
The tagline we use is, what you see is what you pay. The tax-inclusive, unlimited no-contract plans are the new emerging paradigm, and while still early, second quarter results continue to exceed our expectations. We believe the economic situation in many of our urban markets has begun to show modest improvement. Over the past six months, our level of hotline activity has trended down, meaning more customers are paying their bills on time than the previous four quarters. We are pleased with our execution and excited about our progress as we expand the Unlimited, No Contract Service segment and prepare for our transition to LTE. Now I'll turn the call over to Braxton.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tom. Good morning. We reported solid first quarter 2010 operational and financial results this quarter. We have record net additions in the first quarter of approximately 692,000 and ended the quarter with over 7.3 million subscribers, up 21% f
componenttext:
Thank you, Tom. Good morning. We reported solid first quarter 2010 operational and financial results this quarter. We have record net additions in the first quarter of approximately 692,000 and ended the quarter with over 7.3 million subscribers, up 21% from the first quarter of 2009.
Our first quarter consolidated adjusted EBITDA of approximately $224 million was also a record for the company and was up approximately 13% year-over-year. Our strong results this quarter are largely due to two things: our successful introduction of the Wireless for All service plans, coupled with our effective management of our superior cost structure.
We have a very strong balance sheet and substantial liquidity with approximately $1.2 billion in cash and short-term investments. Our strong cash position enables us to look at opportunities for general corporate purposes, which could include opportunistic spectrum acquisitions, corporate development opportunities, future technology initiatives or the retirement of outstanding debt.
Our total leverage was under 4x computed in accordance with the indentures governing our 9.25% senior notes at the end of March, and our net leverage was approximately 2.5x. With debt maturities in late 2013 and 2014, the weighted average cost of debt for the quarter of below 7.5% substantially all of our debt fixed by its nature or through interest rate swaps and with approximately $1.2 billion in cash and short-term investments, we believe we are very well positioned from a balance sheet perspective.
We're proud of the record net subscriber additions this quarter. I'd like to again remind those on the call that we operate in a seasonal business. Now that we are past our major market launches, the first quarter could be an even larger percentage of full-year net subscriber additions. Churn for the quarter was 3.7%, down 130 basis points year-over-year and down 160 basis points on a sequential basis. The dramatic decrease in churn was related to the acceptance of the triple play benefits of our Wireless for All offerings, as Tom has discussed.
Touching on ARPU. Our first quarter 2010 ARPU was $39.83, down $0.57 on a year-over-year basis and down $0.87 on a sequential basis. The decrease in ARPU was primarily due to the introduction of our new Wireless for All service plans in January of 2010, which included all applicable taxes and regulatory fees. The burden on ARPU for our tax-inclusive plans is in the $4 range.  We were able to mitigate the majority of this dilution with the sale of our full range of service plans, including our $60 world unlimited offering.
Our CPGA continues to be one of the lowest of any facilities-based wireless carriers in the U.S. For the first quarter, our CPGA was $146, up $8 sequentially and up approximately $12 year-over-year. The year-over-year increase in CPGA was primarily driven by increased promotional activities in all of our metropolitan areas. Our business continues to scale, and our CPU continues to be among the lowest in the wireless industry. Our CPU for the quarter was $18.79 as compared to $16.69 in the prior year's first quarter. This increase was due primarily to an increase in retention expense due to handset subsidies on existing customers. The inclusion of the regulatory fees and the tax-inclusive service pricing on our Wireless for All customers, as well as costs associated with our unlimited international call plan.
Consolidated adjusted EBITDA for the first quarter was approximately to $224 million, an increase of approximately 13% year-over-year. Our consolidated adjusted EBITDA margin for the quarter was 26% compared to 27% in the first quarter of 2009. Over the trailing 12 months, we have generated record consolidated adjusted EBITDA of approximately $981 million.
I'd like to highlight a few items from the income statement and cash flow statement. In the quarter, on a consolidated basis our service revenue and cost of service grew approximately 17% and 16% to approximately $853 million and $285 million respectively. The increases are primarily due to the growth of our subscriber base. Our consolidated selling, general and administrative expenses were approximately $160 million for the first quarter of 2010, representing an increase of approximately $23 million when compared to the year-ago quarter. This increase is primarily related to increased promotional activities in launching Wireless for All.
We generated $225 million in cash from operating activities in the quarter, a decrease of approximately $82 million from the prior year's first quarter. Offsetting this operating cash flow we incurred capital expenditures of $139 million during the quarter. Our results demonstrate our focus and ability to grow the business while generating positive cash flow. We also generated approximately $23 million in consolidated net income for the first quarter or $0.06 per share compared to $44 million and $0.12 per share for the prior year first quarter. The prior year quarter does include a one-time gain of approximately $25 million on disposal of assets. On a non-GAAP basis, excluding the one-time gain, EPS for the first quarter of 2009 would have been $0.05 per share.
To help the Street with forecasts going forward, based on the amount of tax NOLs we have outstanding at just under $1 billion and including the ongoing amortization of our spectrum licenses for tax purposes, we do not anticipate at this time paying meaningful cash taxes until 2014.
MetroPCS recently made significant changes to the pricing structure of its service plans and has enhanced its market position. Thus far the company has been pleased with the customer interest and results, but in what continues to be a competitive and price-sensitive market, MetroPCS does not anticipate providing financial guidance for fiscal year 2010. Thank you. Roger?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Braxton. Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to report strong quarterly results highlighted by record net addition growth in the quarter and significantly lower churn. Our strategy has and continues to be, to provide predictable, afford
componenttext:
Thank you, Braxton. Good morning, everyone. We are very pleased to report strong quarterly results highlighted by record net addition growth in the quarter and significantly lower churn. Our strategy has and continues to be, to provide predictable, affordable and flexible unlimited service on a no-contract basis. With a robust handset lineup, national coverage, international offerings and our 4G LTE network under construction, we intend to provide subscribers with a post-pay experience in a pre-pay environment. This is truly an exciting time.
After taking an extensive review of our competitive position in the marketplace in early January 2010, we introduced our Wireless for All rate plans. These rate plans significantly re-positioned our business. By moving to tax and regulatory fee-inclusive rate plans, we addressed a desire from the subscriber with simplicity and predictable pricing. We believe these new rate plans and their respective price points solidify our position as offering the best deal in town. 
We believe the change in rate plans, including the elimination of the first month free, lowering handset prices by a corresponding amount and our new marketing campaign have resonated with our customers and have positioned us well for the future. We are approaching a point in time in which the wireless experience will dramatically improve. In our markets, we have been actively building our 4G LTE network, and in early 2010, we have completed our first test calls in both our Dallas, Fort Worth and Las Vegas markets.  The introduction of commercially available 4G LTE is an exciting prospect and illustrates an enhanced technology that promises major improvements to the broadband wireless experience. The world is moving towards 4G LTE service, and here in the U.S., we are the clear leader in the No-Contract segment. The Internet is going mobile, and when we launch 4G LTE, we will be well positioned to enable subscribers to utilize the next-generation network on advanced smartphones and QWERTY handsets. It will be a premium service at an affordable price.
4G LTE will enable exciting new services, including many video applications, but importantly from our perspective, moving towards 4G greater capacity and significantly reducing cost per bit. We believe that one of the significant advantages of LTE is that the cost of adding capacity is substantially less than adding the same amount of capacity on CDMA and has a game-changing consequence. As industry-wide prices for data per bit are declining, LTE enables MetroPCS to further improve its world-class cost structure for broadband data access. 
Part of our long-term strategy is to manage one of the lowest-cost networks of any U.S.-based broadband wireless carrier. The combination of our CPU and CPGA metrics are among the lowest in the industry, and help us compete effectively while delivering healthy, adjusted EBITDA margins. In building our 4G network, we're able to manage our costs while advancing the technology and providing the subscriber with a superior experience. 
Our initial 4G launch will be an IP data overlay over our voice CDMA 1x RTT network. Over time, we will move to an all-IP network. This migration is expected to provide tremendous leverage in CapEx and OpEx, and drives our low-cost operating network strategy in the broadband data era.
Since we began this business we have been judicious in the use of our spectrum, and we have been pioneers in developing technologies to get the most from our spectrum holdings. For example, we have helped to pioneer six sector cell technology and extensive use of DAZ systems that enable our subscribers to enjoy tremendous service coverage and handle exceptionally high traffic on our systems. As we build our 4G network, we will continue to develop and utilize technologies that enable our subscribers to enjoy the benefits of a next-generation network. Additionally with a focus on handsets, we believe we will help to usher in wireless mobility for the way consumers access the Internet using smartphones and QWERTY handsets.
While still in early 2010, we intend to continue our focus on retaining our market and segment leadership. Our Wireless for All campaign has redefined predictability with true, all-in pricing, and we believe we have positioned the company to capitalize on this dominant, emerging paradigm. With over 7.3 million subscribers and nationwide coverage of approximately 220 million POPS, we have grown tremendously in the past few years. We have also evolved the business to deliver our subscribers a post-pay experience on a no-contract pay-in-advance basis. The rapid growth in our subscriber base provides us an opportunity to redefine the wireless experience for the entire industry. Industry analysts projects that the No-Contract Service segment will drive much of the growth in the wireless service industry going forward. Within the Unlimited segment of wireless, total revenue is forecasted to grow at roughly a 25% CAGR through 2013.
From an investment standpoint, we are focused on creating long-term shareholder value. We believe investors should focus on four items when looking at MetroPCS, including: our company's ability to innovate and offer services and products customers truly want; our continued differentiation in the marketplace; our strong balance sheet and the ability to generate free cash flow; and finally, our ability to grow profitably. We've had a record first quarter, and we're pleased so far with our momentum going into the summer months. We're focused on growing the business profitably and launching our 4G service with a focus on maintaining our cost leadership position. Thank you. We'll now move to the Q&A. Operator?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Brett Feldman from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Brett Feldman from Deutsche Bank.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks for all the color around churn, but I was hoping we could just go back to that a little bit. You talked in the past about how this false churn was as high as about 1.5%. That's about the amount by which you showed an improvement in your churn this
componenttext: Thanks for all the color around churn, but I was hoping we could just go back to that a little bit. You talked in the past about how this false churn was as high as about 1.5%. That's about the amount by which you showed an improvement in your churn this quarter, but you also highlighted some other things like the lack of sticker shock, less hotlining. Could you maybe break it down for us in terms of why you think the churn levels improved so much and what was the biggest contributor?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. Good question. I think its a combination of things. We don't have a percentage breakdown for all the elements, but I think the biggest thing is really simplicity. When you think of the rate plan at $45 and $50 and that's what it's going to be
componenttext: This is Tom. Good question. I think its a combination of things. We don't have a percentage breakdown for all the elements, but I think the biggest thing is really simplicity. When you think of the rate plan at $45 and $50 and that's what it's going to be when you get to pay your bill. Sticker shock is tremendously important but the simplicity that there's no other taxes and fees, you can budget that, and it's very simple to come up with two 20s and a five. That's been really important as we've gone forward with the campaign Wireless for All. I think the second piece that we looked at is as we re-trained our whole base, we actually educated every one of our salespeople on the benefits of the rate plans. So as we sell the rate plan, now consumers truly understand what's inside of every rate plan, and we find that they're using more of the elements of the rate plan than they probably did before when the service was given away for free.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the other dimension was the fact that we have talked in the past about the 1.5% and up to we think even 2% of our churn was false. You think you have to reconsider also the fact that the program that we introduced was on January 12, and so a signi
componenttext: I think the other dimension was the fact that we have talked in the past about the 1.5% and up to we think even 2% of our churn was false. You think you have to reconsider also the fact that the program that we introduced was on January 12, and so a significant part of first quarter was not yet fully baked into the first quarter results because we had a carryover for 30 days obviously on those customers that were still on the other rate plan. So I think, yes, we are achieving and realizing that what we've indicated before is a false churn. Whether we're significantly better than that or about the same, I think we're going to be looking at it as we go into second and third quarters.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And remember, Brett, the real benefit here was the elimination of the first month free, and moving that consideration that the customer paid, which really didn't change over to reduced handset prices. So the incentive to go in and buy a new handset to get
componenttext: And remember, Brett, the real benefit here was the elimination of the first month free, and moving that consideration that the customer paid, which really didn't change over to reduced handset prices. So the incentive to go in and buy a new handset to get the first month free was no longer there, and that was really the organic change that has reduced the false churn. But as Roger said, the full impact of that will continue to spill into the second quarter, but also remember that churn has some seasonal components and typically does increase after periods of high net additions.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: So under your old pricing model and your old commission model, the subscriber had an incentive, an existing one had an incentive to kind of deactivate and reactivate so they get the free month. And then the dealer, I believe sort of had an incentive to en
componenttext: So under your old pricing model and your old commission model, the subscriber had an incentive, an existing one had an incentive to kind of deactivate and reactivate so they get the free month. And then the dealer, I believe sort of had an incentive to encourage this because they were getting commission basically on the handset sale itself, and now they're getting a commission off of the ARPU that they're selling. So I'm just wondering are you actually seeing less upgrade activity because neither the customer nor the dealer has an incentive to encourage it?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we're actually seeing the reverse, Brett. We're seeing a significant increase in upgrade activity, which we think, while causing some issues with our CPU, and I'll direct you to the non-GAAP reconciliation in our earnings release, where you can see th
componenttext: No, we're actually seeing the reverse, Brett. We're seeing a significant increase in upgrade activity, which we think, while causing some issues with our CPU, and I'll direct you to the non-GAAP reconciliation in our earnings release, where you can see the retention cost there increasing by $50 million year-over-year. We think it's actually a good news story because people are re-investing in the value proposition of MetroPCS. We think it's a harbinger of future positive benefits from a churn standpoint. And I think it's really driven by two things: It's driven by alignment of the dealer behavior to capture the upgrades; but it's also I think importantly to note that our handset prices have been reduced and we have a very robust line of very desirable handsets, and consumers are coming in and re-investing in the MetroPCS proposition because it's more affordable to do so now.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from Jonathan Chaplin from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: You're next question comes from Jonathan Chaplin from Credit Suisse.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: We saw the Sprint pricing plans come out this morning, and the good news on the face of things is it looks like unlimited pricing is stable, which is certainly better than we thought it would be a few weeks ago. The plans that looked really interesting we
componenttext: We saw the Sprint pricing plans come out this morning, and the good news on the face of things is it looks like unlimited pricing is stable, which is certainly better than we thought it would be a few weeks ago. The plans that looked really interesting were the limited MOU plans for 300 minutes or 1,200 minutes at $25 or $40. I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about to what extent your customer base values the truly unlimited nature of the plans? To what extent are they even aware of how many minutes they're using? And if you have an idea of what the distribution is of users across the minute spectrum, how many of your customers use less than 1,200 minutes and could possibly be susceptible to these new Virgin plans? That would really be helpful. And then one other thing, the $35 million in advertising spend seems like it didn't show up in the quarter. Is that spend getting pushed out to later quarters? Or did the Ranjit and Chad ads come in substantially lower than expected in terms of expense? What's going on with that component?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the first part of your question, if I may, John. The question about whether our customers want unlimited I think is really the issue you're raising, and as you know, we still see the voice minutes in the 2,000-plus category on an average per u
componenttext: Let me take the first part of your question, if I may, John. The question about whether our customers want unlimited I think is really the issue you're raising, and as you know, we still see the voice minutes in the 2,000-plus category on an average per user. There are certain segments, we believe, in this marketplace, where the new Sprint plans might address. We think that we're less susceptible to that because we have a fairly substantial user use now that we've got to an all-inclusive talk, text and web service. So we see heavy use in all those categories. The question really is if there are -- is a segment that really just uses their phone for texting and web service, and that's what they'll be probing. But from our standpoint, we have heavy use across all those three service plans, so we're just going to have to see. We think that the unlimited side gives people the idea that for a relatively, shall we say, cost-effective service to just use it without being concerned about when they're going to be capped on any of those three services.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think something to add to that is that in a segmentation play, we go after the whole market. So we're not trying to divide and conquer that way by figuring out who the right customer is, who's going to walk in the door, who's going to use less than 1,20
componenttext: I think something to add to that is that in a segmentation play, we go after the whole market. So we're not trying to divide and conquer that way by figuring out who the right customer is, who's going to walk in the door, who's going to use less than 1,200, to Roger's point. We let everybody use as much as they want because they're also cutting the cord, which is important to this equation. With regards to the advertising dollars for Ranjit and Chad, I want to let everybody know that we didn't take the full $26 million and spend it on on media. We have a variety of advertising and marketing campaigns that we do over the course of all of our markets. That was just a component in terms of how we went to market. We did a lot of things that were in the Street, that were in the community, but we think as we go forward, we wouldn't need those same levels of spend going forward into the second and third quarters because they're seasonally a little slower. And we've seeded the market with the phenomenal education campaign that doesn't need the same level of spend to continue.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, Jonathan, that really translates into that we under spent the $35 million by $9 million, but when you're looking at CPGA and particularly year-over-year, don't forget that the first quarter of last year we had significantly subsidized our handsets, wh
componenttext: So, Jonathan, that really translates into that we under spent the $35 million by $9 million, but when you're looking at CPGA and particularly year-over-year, don't forget that the first quarter of last year we had significantly subsidized our handsets, which really is not the case with the approach to the marketplace in the first quarter of 2010. So we did pick up some organic benefit there from reduced handset subsidies. And again, when you dig into the numbers that we've disclosed, we can readily see that.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: When I look at the marketing spend, Braxton, it looks like it was only up about $10 sequentially and a little bit more than that year-over-year. I was assuming that all of the $35 million in incremental advertising spend would be captured in that line ite
componenttext: When I look at the marketing spend, Braxton, it looks like it was only up about $10 sequentially and a little bit more than that year-over-year. I was assuming that all of the $35 million in incremental advertising spend would be captured in that line item. So is that not the case? Is it distributed in other categories within CPGA?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Exactly. And I'd like to direct your attention for further analysis to the CPGA reconciliation, and you can see several components there. And again, I'd like to direct your attention to specifically cost of equipment and then normalize that for gross ads
componenttext: Exactly. And I'd like to direct your attention for further analysis to the CPGA reconciliation, and you can see several components there. And again, I'd like to direct your attention to specifically cost of equipment and then normalize that for gross ads and you can see some of what I'm talking about here.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from Phil Cusick.
componenttext: You're next question comes from Phil Cusick.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what people are trying to figure out and you helped us out a little bit on the call with this, is how much of this bps is seasonality, new plans or is the economy getting better? And I know it's really tough to quantify, but can you give us a litt
componenttext: I think what people are trying to figure out and you helped us out a little bit on the call with this, is how much of this bps is seasonality, new plans or is the economy getting better? And I know it's really tough to quantify, but can you give us a little bit of insight as to what your customers are doing outside of seasonality? Are they coming in and paying their bill on a more regular basis than they were, for example, a year ago or six months ago? And is there any shift happening through the quarter on that basis? Trying to figure out the health of that sort of low-end customer.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Phil, I think we talked about sticker shock. When you get a first month under the old way that we did business, you've got a text message, you had a $50 rate plan, you had taxes and fees and that number was brand new to you. It's the first time you ever g
componenttext: Phil, I think we talked about sticker shock. When you get a first month under the old way that we did business, you've got a text message, you had a $50 rate plan, you had taxes and fees and that number was brand new to you. It's the first time you ever got a bill on a text message on your phone. Now when you're in the store, you know exactly what you paid for. The simplicity, the predictability of it truly resonates with everybody. I've been in multiple dealer stores across the country, multiple retail stores, and people -- it takes about three minutes for them to understand exactly what we're presenting in terms of pricing. And then we go to everybody and look at what's in the rate plan, what do you need, what fits your wireless need and our sales process connects 360 all the way around the board. We have a robust set of handsets. We introduced nine handsets last year. We found a really good sweet spot with our QWERTY handsets, and we also mentioned in our survey data that we're seeing a tremendous amount of people who want to leave a contract and get the benefits, as Roger mentioned, of contracted service in a no-contract environment, and that's really important in the economy. We think it's modestly improving, but people don't want the connection to a contract when they can get a lower-priced handset and get all the benefits of the contracted service.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And, Phil, I think your thesis was right on. We have been seeing steady improvement over the last several months going into late last year in the timeliness of the reduction and the number of customers who were hotlining with us.
componenttext: And, Phil, I think your thesis was right on. We have been seeing steady improvement over the last several months going into late last year in the timeliness of the reduction and the number of customers who were hotlining with us.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And has that improved? That's continued to improve through this year?
componenttext: And has that improved? That's continued to improve through this year?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes it has.
componenttext: Yes it has.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from David Barden.
componenttext: You're next question comes from David Barden.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions, if I could. I guess the first is we had a very similar positive net add feeling and call this time last year, kind of high fiving that Boost unlimited hadn't had a big impact. But then we spent the next two quarters regretting that the net
componenttext: Two questions, if I could. I guess the first is we had a very similar positive net add feeling and call this time last year, kind of high fiving that Boost unlimited hadn't had a big impact. But then we spent the next two quarters regretting that the net ads had come from low-end phones that engendered bigger churn, and I was wondering if you could guys just kind of come out and talk to us about if there's going to be a got you in the next two quarters about having revved up net ads so aggressively in 1Q. And then I guess the second question would be, Braxton, on ARPU, you know there's a lot of confusion about all the moving parts in ARPU. You had trade downs, you had repricing, you had a lot of new ads coming in at higher ARPU levels, and then there's some of the old base that may or may not have changed. So could you kind of help us get a sense as to whether we should be anticipating ARPU growth now? Because four out of five gross ads are coming in at higher plans? Or is there still enough of the base that we should be expecting declines? I guess, I'm still confusing where ARPU trends are going.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey David, I think you've been in a few of our meetings with the got you question. It's a really good question. We're looking for the got you. What we see, quite honestly, is in the re-positioning of the service plans. We've really eliminated what we beli
componenttext: Hey David, I think you've been in a few of our meetings with the got you question. It's a really good question. We're looking for the got you. What we see, quite honestly, is in the re-positioning of the service plans. We've really eliminated what we believe is really bad behavior on our consumers part to go and get a new phone at a price where you get a phone and a rate plan that's probably cheaper than if you just paid your rate plan bill. So in paying for the first month of service, that is a major factor in the shift that we've seen. We think that's probably the key inside of everything. Tax-inclusive, unlimited no contract, it's really important, but the re-positioning of how service plans are paid for is probably the number one key. We don't see a got you yet, but we're looking.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the idea that the re-positioning to us is really very important because we not only re-positioned our entire way of we go to market and in doing so aligned the incentives, and I think that's what we're talking about here. We see incentives aligned
componenttext: I think the idea that the re-positioning to us is really very important because we not only re-positioned our entire way of we go to market and in doing so aligned the incentives, and I think that's what we're talking about here. We see incentives aligned on the part of our distribution channels. We see that the customer now is making a more informed decision. So and at the same time, we've been able to, as I had mentioned, that we've been able to, shall we say, transform where the value goes. So now we've reduced our handset prices by a corresponding amount that we used to, shall we say, look towards the first month of free service. Now the customer pays that. So I think this has been a total transformation to a new paradigm, to the all-tax-inclusive paradigm that we think is so critical for this, and I believe that we're looking at stabilizing ARPU as opposed to shifting it in any particular direction. Tom?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could also offer one more thing that I think we mentioned in the script but it bears repeating. With our Samsung Freeform, as an example of what we are doing is we're capitalizing on OEM relationships that are really important to us into the future,
componenttext: If I could also offer one more thing that I think we mentioned in the script but it bears repeating. With our Samsung Freeform, as an example of what we are doing is we're capitalizing on OEM relationships that are really important to us into the future, but for right now we're able to look at handsets by volume, leverage that volume and bring a compelling offer to the consumer. So when they buy a handset that they truly appreciate the form factor and all of its functionality and then they see the rate plan that is now tax inclusive, we really think its a one-two punch that is unparalleled right now.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And David, on your ARPU question, I hope this helps approximately 2/3 of our base is now on tax inclusive. Remember we did a forced migration and then we've had voluntary migration. The voluntary migrations have slowed significantly going into the second
componenttext: And David, on your ARPU question, I hope this helps approximately 2/3 of our base is now on tax inclusive. Remember we did a forced migration and then we've had voluntary migration. The voluntary migrations have slowed significantly going into the second quarter. So we think that we're reaching close to equilibrium on people who are comfortable with where they were versus where they're going. You will see as we continue just to add tax-inclusive customers in the future and old customers churn off, some additional movement there, but I think most of it has been accomplished as of this point or the dramatic change. And you've heard both Tom and Roger talk about the view that our focus is on stabilizing, doing it through product innovation and operational execution.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I think the last comment I would make is that which you alluded to, which is the notion that, yes, the competitive environment will continue to move. We've just seen some of the notes early this morning on what the Sprint repricing is going to be on V
componenttext: And I think the last comment I would make is that which you alluded to, which is the notion that, yes, the competitive environment will continue to move. We've just seen some of the notes early this morning on what the Sprint repricing is going to be on Virgin Mobile and others. Last year, if I would reflect back, I think we had many more changes, which to me was the major paradigm shift between the before-and-after tax world. So now that we've gone and addressed the price points that we think our customers really want, we are on an after-tax basis to regain the predictability side of the equation. I think we've made the significant transition, and I'm sure there will be others going forward that we'll look at in terms of changes and tinkering. But for us, this tax inclusion and regulatory fees was a very significant change in our business, so we don't see it in the same proportion as we did going into, shall we say, second and third quarters of last year.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Simon Flannery.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Simon Flannery.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know you're not breaking out sort of the core and the legacy markets anymore, but can you give us any color around the performance here? Was there any big difference between some of your newer markets, your older markets between different distribution f
componenttext: I know you're not breaking out sort of the core and the legacy markets anymore, but can you give us any color around the performance here? Was there any big difference between some of your newer markets, your older markets between different distribution formats, big-box versus exclusive dealers, any geographic sort of deltas? Anything that really seemed to have sort of out performed the rest? And then on 4G, any major OpEx impact this quarter? And any sort of guidance about how we should think about 4G OpEx as you prepare for launch later this year over the next several quarters?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Simon, so first on the market split-out. So the Northeast being newer, we're still gaining traction. We're still building out the network, we're still getting bigger, but the Northeast is certainly starting to understand who MetroPCS is. We're very, very
componenttext: Simon, so first on the market split-out. So the Northeast being newer, we're still gaining traction. We're still building out the network, we're still getting bigger, but the Northeast is certainly starting to understand who MetroPCS is. We're very, very happy with that. Interestingly enough, all the legacy markets, anything other than the Northeast, they all had a very, very nice quarter. We believe that this didn't just resonate in the Southeast, it resonated in the West, it resonated in the Midwest, every one of our markets had a very, very nice quarter. So we think it's across the board in terms of our performance.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: As it relates to your question on the 4G, I understood it was OpEx and not CapEx that you were focused on?
componenttext: As it relates to your question on the 4G, I understood it was OpEx and not CapEx that you were focused on?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: You can talk about both of them.
componenttext: You can talk about both of them.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: The OpEx, as you know, really translates to backhaul, and we think that we have an opportunity to capitalize on many of the dynamics that are going on there. There will be an increase in OpEx obviously to get the backhaul necessary for 4G, but there will
componenttext: The OpEx, as you know, really translates to backhaul, and we think that we have an opportunity to capitalize on many of the dynamics that are going on there. There will be an increase in OpEx obviously to get the backhaul necessary for 4G, but there will be a more gradual change for us because we will not see the kind of dramatic impact as it really relates this year, primarily because the launches will, as we indicated, take place market-by-market throughout the second half of this year. So there will be a more gradual buildup, but there will be a build up. One thing I might add, though, is that as you go to the backhaul world, it's really a cottage industry and there's very fragmented market. There's not just one player to negotiate with. There are many players. There are some more major ones, agreed, but some of the advantages that we're seeing is in going to an Ethernet foundation, and the value we have in having the kind of traffic that we already incur is that the Ethernet backhaul and the move to that will be, in some cases even be a cost-savings because we have so much traffic now. And we have not taken full advantage of the [ph] staff at each pay (55:22) station that we will have under our 4G scenario. So it's mostly a cost increase, but there are some savings and as the backhaul increases, the pricing is quite dramatic in terms of price per bit at higher backhaul rates and lower backhaul rates. So it's kind of a mixed picture, but it will be gradual this year.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Rick Prentiss.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Rick Prentiss.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to touch on the seasonality point maybe a little bit also. Obviously very strong numbers this year. In your slide deck, you have that nice slide showing the seasonal items all the way from 2002 to 2009. As you look at the second and third quarter
componenttext: I wanted to touch on the seasonality point maybe a little bit also. Obviously very strong numbers this year. In your slide deck, you have that nice slide showing the seasonal items all the way from 2002 to 2009. As you look at the second and third quarter on the slide you provided us, typically second and third quarter have been maybe in the mid-teens as a percent of the annual net adds. If I'm picking up what you're saying correctly, you're suggesting with no major launches, those might be lower as a percent of the year, I guess. And if so, could you give us a framework of what we're thinking about? Instead of mid-teens, are we really looking at single digit? Are we looking at high single digit? Just kind of what your thoughts are.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I guess the thought we have is that we've had a very strong first quarter. The question of what we expect going forward is really going to be determined by what the strength, I think, in second quarter, and I think at this point we see some encouragi
componenttext: Well I guess the thought we have is that we've had a very strong first quarter. The question of what we expect going forward is really going to be determined by what the strength, I think, in second quarter, and I think at this point we see some encouraging results. As a percentage basis, as Braxton indicated, this is kind of a let's not be so terribly optimistic, but we really feel that we have some strong momentum coming out of first quarter. So is it going to be different than the preceding years? That would be a hard one to call, but it's certainly not going to be first quarter running into the second quarter and kind of uniform across the year. We're going to see the seasonality. I really don't think we're going to see or can really articulate anything besides that now, Phil.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: How about within the quarter itself, can you share with us how the quarter progressed and now into April, too, January, March, April? Typically you have the income tax refund situation where customers in the segment are flush with cash. Did you notice any
componenttext: How about within the quarter itself, can you share with us how the quarter progressed and now into April, too, January, March, April? Typically you have the income tax refund situation where customers in the segment are flush with cash. Did you notice any significant shifts between, say, the first three months and now April in the books?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what we really noticed is it seemed to be a week later this year in January, when the refunds really started hitting, but when you look at the distribution of the first quarter, I mean, February is very, very, very strong. and that was the same th
componenttext: I think what we really noticed is it seemed to be a week later this year in January, when the refunds really started hitting, but when you look at the distribution of the first quarter, I mean, February is very, very, very strong. and that was the same this year. January really ramps up towards the end of the month. March, comes down a bps from February but continues to be strong, and then we've indicated that we're pleased with momentum carrying into the second quarter so far. Tom, do you want to add anything?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rick, the only real anomaly that you could put to this, remember, we didn't launch the program until the 12th of January. We actually started working on this about eight months beforehand, but we didn't launch it until January 12. And we didn't roll
componenttext: Yes, Rick, the only real anomaly that you could put to this, remember, we didn't launch the program until the 12th of January. We actually started working on this about eight months beforehand, but we didn't launch it until January 12. And we didn't roll this out to distribution until about the last day of December because obviously it was a pretty big event, and we needed to keep it pretty low key until we had it buttoned up. And as we rolled it out and we got all of our distribution to understand what we were doing, then it was a rush to get inventory allocation because now everybody understood what the pricing was going to be. They were starting to get the message, they understood the simplicity as we went through the training points. So it took us a little bit to get inventory in the channel to the levels that we were comfortable with. So to Braxton's point, was it a week later because of income tax? I think we could go there, but I also think it took a while to get the inventory in the channel for us to really see momentum at the end of January and then carry through into February.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just a quick one on harbinger of, word that you mentioned, Braxton. We hear a lot of buzz in the press about harbinger, Sky Terra building an LTE network, Clearwire last night talked about changing their Intel agreement and moving to LTE probably
componenttext: And then just a quick one on harbinger of, word that you mentioned, Braxton. We hear a lot of buzz in the press about harbinger, Sky Terra building an LTE network, Clearwire last night talked about changing their Intel agreement and moving to LTE probably quicker. Any thoughts about going wholesale on a network? Or are you really bound and determined to build your own network-owned 4G LTE?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're really committed to building our own network, Rick.
componenttext: I think we're really committed to building our own network, Rick.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I thought so. I just wanted to see. When I heard the word harbinger, I thought I'd ask.
componenttext: I thought so. I just wanted to see. When I heard the word harbinger, I thought I'd ask.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from John Hodulik from UBS.
componenttext: You're next question comes from John Hodulik from UBS.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, I apologize, I joined the call a bit late. But just back on the churn issue, did you guys say or is this a situation where you guys believe, aside from normal seasonality, that this new level of churn that we're seeing in the quarter, which is exce
componenttext: Again, I apologize, I joined the call a bit late. But just back on the churn issue, did you guys say or is this a situation where you guys believe, aside from normal seasonality, that this new level of churn that we're seeing in the quarter, which is excellent, is sustainable going forward? And how much of the reduction we're seeing, and again we've talked about this a lot, but how much of this is purely the result of that with Wireless for All you guys are the low-priced, high-value offering on the Street and it just sort of it requires you to maintain that level of competitiveness going forward? And then I guess a little bit of a follow up to Rick's question, how did churn progress through the quarter?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll take a piece of that. I think churn in the quarter, obviously since we just rolled it out, as Braxton mentioned in the 12th of January, we didn't really get a January effect in terms of churn because we were still working on the old model. So you cou
componenttext: I'll take a piece of that. I think churn in the quarter, obviously since we just rolled it out, as Braxton mentioned in the 12th of January, we didn't really get a January effect in terms of churn because we were still working on the old model. So you could just imply from that, that it got better in the quarter simply because we had the product rolled out in February and in March.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: So March would be sort of meaningfully less than the 3 7 that you showed here?
componenttext: So March would be sort of meaningfully less than the 3 7 that you showed here?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: There is seasonality, absolutely. I don't we've looked at this thing any other way. The question is how well will it do into the future and can we continue our momentum. That's all about our execution, and we're going to continue to educate our dealers. W
componenttext: There is seasonality, absolutely. I don't we've looked at this thing any other way. The question is how well will it do into the future and can we continue our momentum. That's all about our execution, and we're going to continue to educate our dealers. We're going to educate our customers on what they're buying. We're going to educate them on what the bill is, what tax-inclusive is, and we've just started. This is in the infancy. We're not every place, where everybody understands who we are and what we are now that we've changed. This is a long process, and we're going to wait and see but we think directionally it's correct.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the WFA and really the level of competitiveness, I think you're suggesting that there may be are we concerned about more price pressures. I think there's a number of other things in the equation and the value of the services, and I really do b
componenttext: In terms of the WFA and really the level of competitiveness, I think you're suggesting that there may be are we concerned about more price pressures. I think there's a number of other things in the equation and the value of the services, and I really do believe that at this point, we've come to a very useful level. But the major transition we feel we've made, so tinkering around the edges I think that's a very strong possibility.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: There's just one more thing as we're in this no-contract unlimited space and we changed everything over, one of the things that now works in our benefit is that you have to be in the community with a support system to support 7.3 million customers monthly
componenttext: There's just one more thing as we're in this no-contract unlimited space and we changed everything over, one of the things that now works in our benefit is that you have to be in the community with a support system to support 7.3 million customers monthly. So going forward, all of our changes were predicated on the fact that we could support our customer base every month as they came to see us and pay their bill. It's always been that way but we're going to see more customers now pay their bill because of the reduction in false churn, and that's a really important part for us going forward. So we feel comfortable that as we progress through the year we'll be able to put our best foot forward as we attempt to always reduce churn and give our customers a better experience.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your last question comes from Jason Armstrong with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your last question comes from Jason Armstrong with Goldman Sachs.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we spoke already that price stabilization for us to really have traction inside of Wireless for All is going to be important. As I mentioned, there's still a lot of people who don't know who we are on this new program. The success of it a it, we'r
componenttext: I think we spoke already that price stabilization for us to really have traction inside of Wireless for All is going to be important. As I mentioned, there's still a lot of people who don't know who we are on this new program. The success of it a it, we're very proud of. We still think there's a lot of the population that we've advertised to, that we've branded to that still needs to soak it in, understand it for what it is. And when that greenfield comes, i.e., their contract is up for being renewed, we figure we have a certain percentage every month based upon 12-month and 24-month contracts that fall out of that space that are now open and will look at us. So we think we're in the right place with our pricing. We think the stability is the right place to be at this point, and it's really predicated upon the minutes of use by our customer base dictates that it's an unlimited model.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you again for participating on today's call. We appreciate your interest and support of MetroPCS, and we look forward to our next quarter of continued progress. Operator?
componenttext: Thank you again for participating on today's call. We appreciate your interest and support of MetroPCS, and we look forward to our next quarter of continued progress. Operator?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, May 06, 2010
