componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes the MetroPCS Communications First Quarter 2010 Conference Call. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect and have a pleasant day.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to the MetroPCS Communications Second Quarter 2010 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Keith Terreri, Vice President and Tr
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to the MetroPCS Communications Second Quarter 2010 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Keith Terreri, Vice President and Treasurer for MetroPCS. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Regina, and good morning, everyone. I'm Keith Terreri, I'd like to welcome you to our second quarter 2010 conference call. The speakers with me this morning are Roger Linquist, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Tom Keys, our
componenttext:
Thank you, Regina, and good morning, everyone. I'm Keith Terreri, I'd like to welcome you to our second quarter 2010 conference call. The speakers with me this morning are Roger Linquist, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Tom Keys, our Chief Operating Officer; and Braxton Carter, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
The format for today's call is as follows: First, Tom will provide an update on a number of operational results and initiatives; then Braxton will review the financial highlights of the second quarter 2010; and Roger will provide an overview of our business, followed by a question-and-answer session.
During today's call, we will refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures. We have reconciled these historical non-GAAP measures to GAAP measures on our earnings release, which is available at www.metropcs.com under the Investor Relations tab. Also this quarter, supplemental slides are available for download and printing on our Investor Relations website.
Although management will not refer to these slides in their prepared comments, we provide these slides as a means to show quarterly highlights and graph historical trends in many of our metrics, as well as compare our cost structure to other major wireless providers. These slides may contain forward-looking statements that may refer to publicly available information.
Before I turn the call over to Tom, I want to remind you that certain information that we will discuss in this conference call may constitute forward-looking statements within the meaning of Federal Securities laws. Words such as believes, anticipates, expects, intends, plans, should, could, would, view, estimates, projects and other similar expressions typically identify forward-looking statements. 
Forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to, statements we make regarding our future plans, our prospects for success in positioning in the highly competitive wireless industry; the effectiveness of our marketing efforts; the expectations of seasonality of our business; forecast when our NOLs will be used; our competitive position in the industry; the value subscribers subscribe to our service; and the growth opportunities available on the wireless industry. 
Furthermore, included in our forward-looking statements are the benefits of false churn reduction; future customer usage patterns, including whether the web goes mobile; the rollout and launch of our 4G LTE networks and services; the cost advantages of LTE; our future LTE services; the impact of Wireless for All and its acceptance by customers; and other statements regarding our objectives, strategies, goals, future events, financial or operational results or performance and other information that is not historical. 
Forward-looking statements involve risk and uncertainties that could cause actual results or the timing of events to materially differ from those made in the forward-looking statements, including, but not limited to, competitive responses; the success of our marketing and cost control initiatives; our ability to launch our LTE network; and changes in taxes and regulatory fees. 
Our forward-looking statements also are subject to general economic conditions, financial, competitive, business, political, regulatory and other factors that are beyond our control, including, but not limited to, the highly competitive nature of our industry; our ability to maintain our cost structure; our and our competitors' planned promotions, marketing and sales initiatives; and our ability to respond and support them; the seasonality of our business, increases or changes in taxes and regulatory fees; and the current economic and environment in the United States. 
Furthermore, our forward-looking statements are subject to our ability to meet the demands and expectations of our customers; our ability to maintain adequate customer care and manage our churn rate; our ability to secure the necessary products, services, spectrum, content and network-infrastructure equipment; changes in customer preferences or demand for our products; our reliance on third parties to provide distribution, products, software and services that are integral to our business; and the performances of our suppliers and other third parties on whom we rely. 
Additionally, our forward-looking statements are subject to the risk factors described in our earnings release and our annual report on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and current reports and Form 8-K, a copy of which can be obtained free of charge from the SEC at www.sec.gov, or from our website or directly from contacting the Investor Relations department. We encourage you to review these. 
We'd like to remind you that the results for the second quarter may not be reflective of results for the full year or any subsequent period. Also I'd like to remind everyone that effective January 1, 2010, we now aggregate our 13 operating segments into one reportable segment. For anyone listening to a taped or webcast replay, or reviewing a written transcript of today's call, please note that all information presented is current only as of August 5, 2010, and should be considered valid only as  of August 5, 2010, regardless of the date reviewed, read or replayed. 
MetroPCS disclaims any intention or obligation to revise or update any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or developments or otherwise, except as required by law. The company does not plan to update or reaffirm guidance except through formal public disclosure pursuant to Regulation FD. Certain terms we used in today's call are registered trademarks of MetroPCS. We intend to file our quarterly report on Form 10-Q for the period ended June 30, 2010, with the SEC by August 9. 
And at this time, I'd like to turn the call over to our Chief Operating Officer, Tom Keys.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. Good morning, everyone. The transformation of our company with Wireless for All continued in the second quarter, where we delivered record subscriber net additions of 303,000. I'm also very pleased to report record low churn of 3.3%, dow
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. Good morning, everyone. The transformation of our company with Wireless for All continued in the second quarter, where we delivered record subscriber net additions of 303,000. I'm also very pleased to report record low churn of 3.3%, down 250 basis points from the second quarter of 2009 and down approximately 40 basis points sequentially. The strong subscriber growth and record low churn this quarter, combined with our low-cost operating structure, drove record-adjusted EBITDA of $322 million, representing growth of approximately 38% in the quarter. 
We are focused on executing on our Wireless for All initiatives. Our record low churn in the quarter was primarily driven by the acceptance of our Wireless for All offerings, including a significant increase in year-over-year reactivations. Clearly, subscribers are reconfirming their choice in MetroPCS. 
We believe our Wireless for All go-to-market strategy reasserted our no-contract segment leadership. Importantly, Wireless for All was not just a rate-plan change. It was a multi-faceted transformation of our business system, which took extensive planning and execution. The no-contract wireless industry continues to evolve, and we are optimizing our business for sustained execution.
Our second quarter results are truly a continuation of the positive impact we saw from Wireless for All in the first quarter of the year. Six months into the year, customer response has exceeded our expectations, and we are pleased with our execution as we believe our current price points provide outstanding value to the consumer. 
We have demonstrated that there remains significant growth opportunity within the no-contract segment. As of June 2010, in the aggregate of all of our operating markets, MetroPCS has approximately 1/3 of all no-contract subscribers, according to a third-party study. The no-contract segment is growing quickly. And for the last several quarters, a third party estimates that over 50% of total wireless decisions are choosing no-contract wireless service plans. 
Other wireless companies recognize the growth opportunities within the no-contract space, and we have seen increasing segmentation and differentiation over the past 12 months. Our Wireless for All initiatives, low-cost operating structure and unlimited service plans are specifically tailored and engineered to capture the growth within this segment.
Churn this quarter declined both year-over-year and sequentially. The decline in churn is primarily due to the continued benefit of the move to Wireless for All tax-inclusive plans. Approximately 2/3 of our customers are now on tax-inclusive plans at the end of the second quarter. Our customers now pay for the first month of service, with all taxes and fees included, and this has reduced first-month bill shock. 
We have also lowered handset prices by a corresponding amount. So the net-net of customer spending is the same amount of cash in the initial transaction. Without a free month of service, subscribers now upgrade their handset and leave their current number in service.
Our Wireless for All transformation and our focus on our distribution channel enables us to optimize our rate-plan mix, thus stabilizing ARPU and maximizing customer satisfaction. As we move forward, we believe the launch of premium 4G service offerings could have a positive impact on ARPU.
A key component in our record second quarter net subscriber additions is delivering to consumers handsets that they really want. Subscribers increasingly use their handsets to access the Internet, as broadband has truly gone mobile.
Smartphones and QWERTY handsets are popular among our subscribers, and we will continue to introduce compelling handsets to our lineup from OEMs, including Samsung, LG, Kyocera, Huawei, ZTE and Motorola. We were very pleased with our recent introduction of our next-generation BlackBerry Curve to the northeast markets. Users of our BlackBerry service save approximately half of what they would spend with one of the national wireless contract providers. 
We are very pleased with our execution six months into the year. We believe we will see our typical third quarter seasonality and would expect lower net subscriber additions and higher churn for the third quarter consistent with historical norms.
In our operating markets, competitive pressures, increased competition from big-box retailers and the need for carriers to meet and exceed expectations are realities. While we acknowledge these pressures, we have modeled our annual expectations accordingly to maintain profitable growth as we encounter competition, support our distribution partners and provide no-contract unlimited wireless services to over 95 million potential customers. We believe national carriers will have great difficulty in conducting an isolated price war in the no-contract segment without directly impacting the contract subscriber base. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Braxton.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning. We reported strong second quarter 2010 operational and financial results. We had record second quarter net additions of 303,000 and ended the quarter with over 7.6 million subscribers, up 22% from the second quarter of 2009. Our
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good morning. We reported strong second quarter 2010 operational and financial results. We had record second quarter net additions of 303,000 and ended the quarter with over 7.6 million subscribers, up 22% from the second quarter of 2009. Our second quarter consolidated adjusted EBITDA of $322 million was a record for the company, and it was up approximately 38% year-over-year. 
Our strong results this quarter are largely due to two factors: Our successful launch and execution of our Wireless for All service plans, coupled with our focused management on our superior cost structure. We have a very strong balance sheet and substantial liquidity with approximately $1.1 billion in cash and short-term investments.
Our strong cash position enables us to look at opportunities for general corporate purposes, which could include opportunistic spectrum acquisitions, corporate development opportunities, future technology initiatives or the retirement of outstanding debt.
We took a key step in terming out the maturity schedule of our capital structure by recently completing an amendment and extension of our existing term B credit facility. We were pleased with the reception of this transaction in the marketplace, whereby we extended $1 billion of our $1.54 billion in secured debt by three years to 2016. We felt that increasing the LIBOR spread for the amount extended by 125 basis points for this three-year extension is a prudent trade-off.
Our total leverage was under 3.5x, computed in accordance with the indebtedness governing 9 1/4% senior notes at the end of June, and our net average is now below 2.5x. With debt maturities in late 2013 and 2014 and now, 2016; the weighted average cost of debt for the quarter of below 7.5%; the majority of our debt fixed, by its nature or through interest rate swaps; and with approximately $1.1 billion in cash and short-term investments, we believe we are very well-positioned from a balance-sheet perspective.
We're proud of our record net subscriber additions for this quarter. I'd like to again remind those on the call that we operate in a seasonal business. Historically, the third quarter has generally seen lower net subscriber additions and a sequential increase in churn. This is our expectation for the third quarter of 2010.
Churn for the quarter was 3.3%, down 250 basis points year-over-year and down 40 basis points on a sequential basis. The decrease in churn was primarily driven by the acceptance of our Wireless for All offerings, including the decline in false churn, as a combination of our realigned dealer incentives and stronger value propositions took effect.
Our second quarter 2010 ARPU was $39.84, down $0.68 on a year-over-year basis and up $0.01 on a sequential basis. The decrease in ARPU year-over-year was primarily due to the introduction of our new Wireless for All service plans in January 2010, which included all applicable taxes and regulatory fees. The burden on ARPU for our tax-inclusive plans is in the $4 range. We were able to mitigate the majority of this dilution with the sale of our full range of service plans, including our $60-world unlimited offering. We are pleased with the stabilization of ARPU experienced in the second quarter. 
Our CPGA continues to be one of the lowest of any facilities-based carriers in the United States. For the second quarter, our CPGA was $164, up approximately $4 over the prior year's second quarter. As you can see in our supplemental slides, our current cost of churn is approximately $5, which is truly best-of-class. 
Our business continues to scale, and our CPU continues to be among the lowest in the wireless industry. Our CPU for the quarter was $17.90 as compared to $16.82 in the prior year's second quarter. This increase was due primarily to an increase from retention expenses related to handset subsidies on existing customers, the inclusion of regulatory fees in our Wireless for All customers, as well as the costs associated with our unlimited international calling plan. The increase in CPU would have been much higher without the continued scaling of our business.
Consolidated adjusted EBITDA for the second quarter was $322 million, an increase of approximately 38% year-over-year. Our consolidated adjusted EBITDA margin for the quarter was 35% compared to 30% in the second quarter of 2009. Over the trailing 12 months, we have generated record consolidated adjusted EBITDA of approximately $1.1 billion.
I'd like to highlight a few items from the income statement and cash flow statement. In the quarter, on a consolidated basis, our service revenue and cost of service grew 20% and approximately 15% to $922 million and $308 million, respectively. The increases are primarily due to the growth of our subscriber base. 
Our consolidated selling, general and administrative expenses were approximately $159 million for the second quarter of 2010, representing an increase of $16 million when compared to a year-ago quarter. We generated $112 million in cash from operating activities in the quarter, a decrease of $47 million from the prior year's second quarter. The decrease was primarily driven by an increase in cash used for working capital. 
We incurred capital expenditures of approximately $176 million during the second quarter of 2010. During the quarter, our unlevered free cash flow was approximately $146 million. Our results demonstrate our focus and ability to grow the business while generating cash flow over the long term. We believe free cash flows will increase significantly, as we complete our LTE deployment in 2010 and early 2011.
We generated approximately $80 million in consolidated net income during the second quarter, representing year-over-year growth of over 200% or $0.22 per share, compared to $26 million or $0.07 per share in the prior-year quarter. 
Now I'd like to turn it over to Roger.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Braxton, and good morning. Today, we reported outstanding quarterly results driven by a strong net subscriber additions, lower churn and a continued focus on expense management. Our consolidated adjusted EBITDA was the highest in company histor
componenttext:
Thank you, Braxton, and good morning. Today, we reported outstanding quarterly results driven by a strong net subscriber additions, lower churn and a continued focus on expense management. Our consolidated adjusted EBITDA was the highest in company history, at $322 million for the second quarter and $1.1 billion in the last 12 months.
In the first six months of 2010, we have added approximately 1 million subscribers to our base. At the end of the second quarter, we served over 7.6 million subscribers. This represents total subscriber growth of over 22% from the second quarter of last year. 
The no-contract market is the core of our business model, and we have focused on the unlimited segment to drive our cost leadership. We believe that the no-contract segment will continue to expand in the U.S. and, ultimately, approach levels of adoption seen in some European countries.
Wireless for All introduced in early 2010 reposition MetroPCS to capitalize on the opportunity within the fastest growing area of wireless to no-contract segment. We provide a postpaid experience in the no-contract environment. We intend to continue to execute on our strategy of providing the subscribers predictable, affordable and flexible wireless service. By offering a number of compelling services in our rate plan, we believe we provide real value to wireless consumers. 
So wireless industry is dynamic, and our move to Wireless for All highlights our ability to innovate. It requires significant systems development and changes at every level of the organization. But more importantly, in a highly competitive marketplace, it also highlights our ability to be a nimble competitor. 
I'd like to highlight some of the new services we anticipate offering in the future. We are in the process of creating a proprietary MetroPCS studio. When introduced, we expect this application will provide streaming video, full-track downloads and television channels, all powered by our 4G LTE network. As we move towards the start of launching 4G LTE service in the second half of this year, we believe our subscribers will increasingly use their web-based handset to fully access a multimedia environment recognizing the phone's transition to an entertainment device.
LTE leadership will further improve our service features and ability to gain market share, while maintaining cost and price differentials. This affords MetroPCS the opportunity to potentially be the only carrier offering a range of service rate plans, payment options and handsets to the growing no-contract market segment.
We are excited with the upcoming launch of 4G LTE services in our metropolitan areas. 4G LTE services are about creating a multimedia data experience for our subscribers. In the no-contract segment, we are clearly the leader in 4G LTE network deployment for smartphone devices. We anticipate our first two market launches will be in Dallas-Fort Worth and Las Vegas, with the Samsung Craft, the first LTE smartphone approved by the FCC [Federal Communications Commission].
In the future, we also look forward to migrating our CDMA voice customers to 4G LTE VoIP. We believe this will provide a significant cost advantage and makes full use of our spectrum resources, while providing a substantial additional capacity. We believe the investment we are making now will provide our wireless subscribers the first 4G LTE smartphone in the no-contract wireless segment. 
And even more exciting, it's possible that in the future, subscribers will have multiple devices connected to the network, providing an opportunity to significantly exceed penetration rates of 100%. Initially, the smartphone will be the primary device we will offer to access our 4G LTE network. But in the future, the evolution will undoubtedly incorporate additional devices like netbooks and tablets. 
It's exciting to look out over the next several years and envision the 4G LTE environment, with opportunity to drive incremental revenue and value for the business. Overall, we are very pleased with our second quarter and first half of 2010 results. 
The wireless industry is very competitive. But the no-contract space is where the growth opportunity exists, and we are the leaders in this space. We are executing well, and effectively balancing financial performance with subscriber growth. Our Wireless for All strategy enable us to expand on our leadership position in the no-contract space. We are committed to the next evolution of our business: 4G, LTE, broadband services. 
Thank you. We'll now move to Q&A. Operator?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Brett Feldman with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Brett Feldman with Deutsche Bank.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, I appreciate the all the color on what we should expect in the third quarter for net adds and churn. I was hoping we could just talk a little bit about what we should be thinking in terms of margins in the second half of the year. And I'm just wond
componenttext: First, I appreciate the all the color on what we should expect in the third quarter for net adds and churn. I was hoping we could just talk a little bit about what we should be thinking in terms of margins in the second half of the year. And I'm just wondering if we should be layering in any expenses associated with LTE. And then the second question kind of gets to your distribution strategy. You guys have historically relied on sort of a branded distribution channel, but some of your peers are talking more and more about the high importance of being the national channel. So I was hoping you could just talk a bit about that as well.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me hit the first part of that, Brett. As we go forward and put in the 4G services, we would expect some additional costs. As you know, backhaul will be one of those items, which will be an increase in our OpEx. And so we would see that, however we are
componenttext: Let me hit the first part of that, Brett. As we go forward and put in the 4G services, we would expect some additional costs. As you know, backhaul will be one of those items, which will be an increase in our OpEx. And so we would see that, however we are still scaling in subscribers. So from a go-forward standpoint, we don't see major variables that are acting to change what we would see as margin performance year-to-date. Tom, would you like to take on the second half of that?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brad. I think the reliance on national retail big-box to date has been immaterial. And what Metro has traditionally found and what's worked for us is a benefit by being in the community on a more granular basis. And that difference has served us wel
componenttext: Sure, Brad. I think the reliance on national retail big-box to date has been immaterial. And what Metro has traditionally found and what's worked for us is a benefit by being in the community on a more granular basis. And that difference has served us well to date, and we believe that we all continue down that path.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you're not seeing any change in store traffic or customer behavior? It just seems that other operators are feeling that if you're not in the big-box channels right now, you're eventually going to miss the flow. So I'm just wondering why did you guys s
componenttext: And you're not seeing any change in store traffic or customer behavior? It just seems that other operators are feeling that if you're not in the big-box channels right now, you're eventually going to miss the flow. So I'm just wondering why did you guys sort of have as latent perspective on this?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well let me try it this way. I think we've been very effective in the channel of distribution where we distribute, and I think it is more in a community environment. Big box has been, as it always has been for manufacturers and service providers, a kind o
componenttext: Well let me try it this way. I think we've been very effective in the channel of distribution where we distribute, and I think it is more in a community environment. Big box has been, as it always has been for manufacturers and service providers, a kind of a one-stop shopping. So there is a, shall we say, an obvious reception for let's-go-to-big-box. But big box, as you know, is very crowded at this point. And we don't think the level of service, the convenience for our customers and the actual customer support you get at the point-of-sale is as good as you would get in the standard big box. So we're very happy with our channels.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: So based under your plans, taking what you've been doing for the time being, we shouldn't expect a major change in the distribution model?
componenttext: So based under your plans, taking what you've been doing for the time being, we shouldn't expect a major change in the distribution model?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: You shouldn't expect a major change. Obviously, we'll take advantage of, and we are in big box today, Best Buy and Wal-Mart. So it's not that we're not there, the question is that we're not depending on big box to basically carry the load.
componenttext: You shouldn't expect a major change. Obviously, we'll take advantage of, and we are in big box today, Best Buy and Wal-Mart. So it's not that we're not there, the question is that we're not depending on big box to basically carry the load.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Moffett with Stanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Moffett with Stanford Bernstein.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to turn my attention to the larger industry for a second. We saw a T-Mobile report, relatively weak results, quite weak results in prepaid this morning. Tracfone's results were a little softer than we would have expected. It looks like the overal
componenttext: I wanted to turn my attention to the larger industry for a second. We saw a T-Mobile report, relatively weak results, quite weak results in prepaid this morning. Tracfone's results were a little softer than we would have expected. It looks like the overall prepaid market, even with the strength that you guys had in the quarters, net adds were down 50% year-over-year. Can you just comment on that at all? Is that anything close to what your market expectations were? And what do you think is going on with what looked like, until this quarter, was the real growth engine of the market?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Excellent question. There's some concern about the fact that the so-called pay-in-advance, prepaid market is not getting the growth that everybody expects. I think there's several things operating here. As you know, we are in a very difficult economic env
componenttext: Excellent question. There's some concern about the fact that the so-called pay-in-advance, prepaid market is not getting the growth that everybody expects. I think there's several things operating here. As you know, we are in a very difficult economic environment. And we have said all along, for the last, really, year and a half, that this has been an overhang on the marketplace. But there's one thing that I'd like to point out that I try to cover in my comments and that is, that our objective in expanding this no-contract segment is to step up our ability to provide not only handsets but services that people would expect in a post-pay environment. We don't have parity now. I mean, let's be very blunt about it. The no-contract segment, in most cases, is not at parity with what you can receive in services and in handset selection from the contract side of the business. So we think we have a great opportunity, and 4G is really a transformation of our network. And it gives us the opportunity to get at, shall we say, at parity, obviously, with the exception of exclusive handset deals that have permeated the carrier business in the last few years. But nevertheless, I think you're seeing there's a tremendous increase in smartphones. I think you're going to see the emergence, as we already have, of the Android and competing with the Apple operating system in handset. So I think what we'll see is that the No-contract segment is going to have a much stronger parity, and that causes a real issue for contract providers because of the concerns for, shall we say, shifting sales, if not cannibalization into the no-contract space. That is our space. It is a cost-based strength that we have. We intend to use it. And now we're approaching, we think, an opportunity to be at greater parity with the postpaid side of the business.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And could I just slip in one more question, a company-specific question if I could. You're roaming agreement with Leap in light of the announcement that Leap made that they'll be doing a wholesale MB&O with Sprint. How does that work when they're going to
componenttext: And could I just slip in one more question, a company-specific question if I could. You're roaming agreement with Leap in light of the announcement that Leap made that they'll be doing a wholesale MB&O with Sprint. How does that work when they're going to be selling services in regions that you have your network? I assume that your MB&O agreement, or your roaming agreement, with Leap would not let them continue to operate in your network and your markets, is that right?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. It's unaffected.
componenttext: Right. It's unaffected.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: So but just to clarify, does that mean -- they've never sold services in your markets before under their own brand name. So how does that work given your roaming agreement?
componenttext: So but just to clarify, does that mean -- they've never sold services in your markets before under their own brand name. So how does that work given your roaming agreement?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, our roaming agreement does not cover the markets in the same manner as they cover -- home markets as it does markets that are outside of their networks. So there's differentiations. We don't see this as a threat, bottom line.
componenttext: Well, our roaming agreement does not cover the markets in the same manner as they cover -- home markets as it does markets that are outside of their networks. So there's differentiations. We don't see this as a threat, bottom line.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Prentiss with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rick Prentiss with Raymond James.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of points. Obviously, impressive improvements in churn, seasonally going up next quarter, I understand. But talk to us to a little bit about is mid-threes kind of the new what used to be five? Could it go any lower? What would cost churn to go in
componenttext: A couple of points. Obviously, impressive improvements in churn, seasonally going up next quarter, I understand. But talk to us to a little bit about is mid-threes kind of the new what used to be five? Could it go any lower? What would cost churn to go in either direction? Just trying to look at kind of the new reality of the Wireless for All world.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Rick, I think the seasonality that we indicated in our remarks, I think we have a new reality. We indicated for some number of years that we had an element of false churn and we do believe that, that has significantly decreased. It'll never go to ze
componenttext: Well, Rick, I think the seasonality that we indicated in our remarks, I think we have a new reality. We indicated for some number of years that we had an element of false churn and we do believe that, that has significantly decreased. It'll never go to zero, but it significantly decreased. I think the other factor that's been a big impact in first and second quarter has been the fact that our Wireless for All services have really provided a better alternative, we think, than the industry. So what I would say, I guess, is that, that, plus the fact that we have seen a resurgence, and this is tied really to the false churn of reactivations. That this correlates very well with the fact that our subscribers now are upgrading their handset. I think as Tom remarked earlier, and instead of changing their phone number or going off service. So there is a new reality. I think you've clearly picked up on that. I won't be projecting what churn rates will be, but I do think the net effect will be lower churns going forward. And how low can we go, I'm going to avoid that one, Rick.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the ARPU side, what mix are your customers taking into plans as you look out there? How are your sales agents through your different distribution channels, how are they trying to position people? Just trying to think through the ARPU-trend question.
componenttext: On the ARPU side, what mix are your customers taking into plans as you look out there? How are your sales agents through your different distribution channels, how are they trying to position people? Just trying to think through the ARPU-trend question.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our sales agents, Rick, if you look at our distribution channels, the change for Wireless All (sic) [Wireless for All] really did a really big thing to our customer experience at the counter. Now that you're paying for the first month and not receiving it
componenttext: Our sales agents, Rick, if you look at our distribution channels, the change for Wireless All (sic) [Wireless for All] really did a really big thing to our customer experience at the counter. Now that you're paying for the first month and not receiving it free. The experience, the education, the explanation of what you're buying actually is probably four to 5x longer just from a pure minutes and time-wise at the counter. So a customer walks out of the store understanding what's in a $45 or $50 rate plan, or $60 with ILD. Where before, they spent more time picking out a handset since that was the primary driver, and they went to the counter, and the rate plan probably wasn't as important. They got the first month bill with the $50-rate plan, taxes and fees on top of that, they get sticker shock and then they run away from us at a much easier rate. So what we've done now is we've forced the training at the counter, so when you realize that you're getting a $50-rate plan, you know everything that's in it. It's really important to the people selling it, and we've aligned behavior with our distribution partners to help train better and sell the value of the rate plan.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rick, I'd like to add that we're very, very thoughtful with Wireless for All in the build up of the value proposition under each rate plan. And Tom, the talks about the first quarter, that the vast majority of sales mix that we were seeing were on the $45
componenttext: Rick, I'd like to add that we're very, very thoughtful with Wireless for All in the build up of the value proposition under each rate plan. And Tom, the talks about the first quarter, that the vast majority of sales mix that we were seeing were on the $45 higher plan. Now based upon the ARPU results, that absolutely continues to be the story. Rate plan ARPU is not the only component of ARPU. There's family-plan dilution, there's other items that impact it. But our organization, I think, has done a phenomenal job from an execution standpoint in our distribution channels of really educating the consumer as to what our value propositions are. And you're seeing it in a stabilization of our ARPU up in the very high-39s.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I'd like to just add one thing, Rick, if I could. The thing that we have to understand is it does a lot of compelling rate plans in the industry. Officially, it comes down to execution. We could have very good rate plans but if we don't execute on it,
componenttext: And I'd like to just add one thing, Rick, if I could. The thing that we have to understand is it does a lot of compelling rate plans in the industry. Officially, it comes down to execution. We could have very good rate plans but if we don't execute on it, we don't receive the benefit of it. So this took a lot of planning and a lot of focus to have a transformation whereby everyone of our distribution partners were trained and then retrained again on how to do this. So we've been pleased with the results.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: On handset mix, how are smartphone selling? Is there like an update as far as good, better, best kind of mix of handsets that are going out the store?
componenttext: On handset mix, how are smartphone selling? Is there like an update as far as good, better, best kind of mix of handsets that are going out the store?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have an increasing handset mix. I think that's probably the best way for us to address that. Tom, would like to add to that?
componenttext: Well, we have an increasing handset mix. I think that's probably the best way for us to address that. Tom, would like to add to that?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we found a lot of success, number one, with QWERTYs, obviously not smarts, but just QWERTYs. Our smartphones and our QWERTYs go very nicely on the higher end. Although you could always understand that, that percentage is going to be lower on the h
componenttext: Yes. So we found a lot of success, number one, with QWERTYs, obviously not smarts, but just QWERTYs. Our smartphones and our QWERTYs go very nicely on the higher end. Although you could always understand that, that percentage is going to be lower on the higher end. The next thing we're excited about is to get in some full-touch handsets that will have Android on them, and the evolution to the third and fourth quarter. One of the things that we believe, as you heard me talk today, is we need to have multiple OEMs with us. We need to work hard with them to continue to develop handsets, not to get a stale lineup. And I think today, you'll find us in most of our distribution partners for anywhere between 15 to 18 SKUs. And although that could have some additional back-end costs that we recognize, the choice for the customer for them to stay with a compelling handset, it's really important.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think just to, again, to add to that because it's a very important subject and I try to touch on it before to achieve this notion of parity, and I do that under quotation marks. But the fact is that our lineup will include a number of Android devices go
componenttext: I think just to, again, to add to that because it's a very important subject and I try to touch on it before to achieve this notion of parity, and I do that under quotation marks. But the fact is that our lineup will include a number of Android devices going forward before the end of the year. And next year will be a very strong offering of units that I think everybody would classify as either QWERTY or smartphones with a pretty heavy mix of smartphones. I think this is a critical transformation for us in the pay-in-advance, or for that matter, the prepaid industry as usually described. Because the services offered is really not from looking back up to the same standard as you would expect to get in the post-pay environment. And so I think this will be terribly important, and prices of smartphones are coming down. I think we said a year and a half ago that we would expect to get below $100 in the next few years for an LTE smartphone. I think we're certainly would come back and say, that is a reality, that will happen and it may happen sooner than people think. So this is an important driver. Handsets and services that come with it, I think that's a very important element of our business.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jonathan Chaplin with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jonathan Chaplin with Credit Suisse.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just like to follow-up on Rick's question a little bit. So we're in a bit of a new realm for churn. Looking back, actually, last year, churn didn't go up in 3Q. But if I look up it at prior years, it seems to have gone up by about 30 basis points in the l
componenttext: Just like to follow-up on Rick's question a little bit. So we're in a bit of a new realm for churn. Looking back, actually, last year, churn didn't go up in 3Q. But if I look up it at prior years, it seems to have gone up by about 30 basis points in the last couple of years. Is that about the magnitude of churn increase we should be looking for this time around? And then on ARPU, Braxton, it sounds like you're doing really well at selling the higher-rate plans, but that's offset by family-plan dilution. Does that keep ARPU from expanding from these levels? Do you think it bounces around this $39 to $40 range? Or is there some level of saturation of family plans where the impact of selling higher-rate plans actually drives ARPU up from these levels? And then finally, I apologize for the laundry list, but on CCU [cash cost per user], it actually came in lower than we expected given the cost pressures from the new rate plans. Does CCU decline from here as the business scales? Or there's some one-time impacts that we should think about?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Jonathan. Let me take a couple and I'd like to ask Roger to talk about our view on ARPU and the dynamics associated with that, especially as we enter the LTE realm. But let's first talk about CPU, and I think you bring up a very important point that
componenttext: Sure, Jonathan. Let me take a couple and I'd like to ask Roger to talk about our view on ARPU and the dynamics associated with that, especially as we enter the LTE realm. But let's first talk about CPU, and I think you bring up a very important point that our business continues to scale. But one of the foundational tenets of our company has always been a laser focus on cost control. And it wasn't kind of does your early [ph] thing that which has started doing a year ago because we're really back to the foundation and forming of our company, and it's something that we are always focused on. And I think you'd see those in all of our metrics and the results, but the power of scale is significant. You're looking at a world-class CPU of a company that is a little less than 7 million subs versus what you have with very, very large industry players that are many multiples the size of us. So yes, we do see that there are some real benefits coming from scale. I came up earlier in the call that there will be some expenses associated with LTE. And some of those expenses will be a step function as we build and rollout the markets, and that will cause some short-term pressure. But as Roger very clearly indicated, we believe that we'll more than adequately cover that with the scale of our business over time. On the churn equation, we're not really going to give specific guidance as to what churn is going to be for the third quarter. But we wanted to make it clear that the expectation is that it would increase, and I think very astutely. You look at the trends that we've seen year-over-year and last year was certainly an anomaly. But there has been historically a 30 basis point, plus or minus, five, 10 basis point increase in churn going from the second to third quarter. The dynamics this year on is we have Wireless for All not in place for all of the first quarter. So you did see some residual benefit of having a full quarter of that in the second quarter. So you need to take that into account when you're trying to model this. And I think the final thing I can say about churn, as Tom mentioned in his part of the prepared presentation, that we expected that churn will increase generally consistent with historic norms. With that, I'd like to turn it over to Roger to talk a little bit about your question on ARPU.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me try to expand on this. Certainly, we think that our introduction of LTE will be a strong factor in adding, shall we say, services at higher ARPU. We do envision having the, as we've said, the Metro store or Metro media studio. So we will be lo
componenttext: Yes, let me try to expand on this. Certainly, we think that our introduction of LTE will be a strong factor in adding, shall we say, services at higher ARPU. We do envision having the, as we've said, the Metro store or Metro media studio. So we will be looking at rate plans that will be north of what we have today, but not very far north of what we have today. The other side is the pressure from competitive standpoint that we don't get too far out of our skin in terms of the overall ARPU for all our services. We are adding applications, but I think that that's on the margin relatively small. So depending on the build up of LTE, and I think I would think about it more in this light, that it will be more gradual. We will not be offering services in all our markets until the end of the year or very early next year, depending upon the build program. And we would expect that to be an impact at that point. So I wouldn't see great jumps, I would see more gradualism. We'll continue to be competitive. But that's the one area that I identify that we would have some opportunity for upward movement.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins with Citi Investment Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins with Citi Investment Research.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of quick questions. First, as you look at ARPU, are there any impacts from roaming from any of the partners whether it's from the Leap or other players that you may allow onto your network? And the second question was, if you look at the inv
componenttext: Just a couple of quick questions. First, as you look at ARPU, are there any impacts from roaming from any of the partners whether it's from the Leap or other players that you may allow onto your network? And the second question was, if you look at the inventory balance, it looked like it picked up meaningfully in the quarter. Anything you read into that in terms of new products you're getting to roll out or new direction with respect to your device lineup?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. The ARPU roaming revenue is really de minimis to our overall ARPU numbers that are reported. So I think that clearly answers that. We have been building inventory. As you can see with our handset lineup, we have a very robust lineup of QWERTY and sm
componenttext: Sure. The ARPU roaming revenue is really de minimis to our overall ARPU numbers that are reported. So I think that clearly answers that. We have been building inventory. As you can see with our handset lineup, we have a very robust lineup of QWERTY and smartphones, recently launched the BlackBerry next-generation that which included the AWS, which directly benefited our northeast markets. And as Tom likes to say, you can't sell out of an empty wagon. You need to have adequate inventory on hand to support the growth that you're forecasting.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think the summary is that there's a handset-mix demand that we see. And we think that's very positive because that usually indicates an interest in greater services. We do think web browsing has become, shall we say, a very strong story of deve
componenttext: Yes, and I think the summary is that there's a handset-mix demand that we see. And we think that's very positive because that usually indicates an interest in greater services. We do think web browsing has become, shall we say, a very strong story of development this year for us.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just within that context, do you feel any pressure, or do you see any opportunity of adjusting your subsidy structure for integrated devices, or smartphones, to try to get a larger share of that market place?
componenttext: And just within that context, do you feel any pressure, or do you see any opportunity of adjusting your subsidy structure for integrated devices, or smartphones, to try to get a larger share of that market place?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me make sure I understand your question. When you say integrated devices, are we talking smartphones or are we talking about cards and dongles?
componenttext: Let me make sure I understand your question. When you say integrated devices, are we talking smartphones or are we talking about cards and dongles?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Smartphones or QWERTY-keyboard devices. Integrated messaging and advanced multimedia features.
componenttext: Smartphones or QWERTY-keyboard devices. Integrated messaging and advanced multimedia features.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that was the essence of what I was attempting to say is that because of what we see in demand, and that is demand on network, as well as in the stores, that we're seeing a very significant increase in our customer base interest in web browsin
componenttext: Yes. I think that was the essence of what I was attempting to say is that because of what we see in demand, and that is demand on network, as well as in the stores, that we're seeing a very significant increase in our customer base interest in web browsing. And so that nationally puts us into handsets that are more suitable for this type of experience, so the shift really. And the shift in what our customers are interested in at the counter. And the short-term impact of that is a more significant increase in inventory as the price per unit increases.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I was just thinking about the subsidy itself. So in addition to selling more of those devices, is there an appetite to lower the cost of the device to the customer, thereby, increasing the subsidy to try out to get more share of the market or addressi
componenttext: And I was just thinking about the subsidy itself. So in addition to selling more of those devices, is there an appetite to lower the cost of the device to the customer, thereby, increasing the subsidy to try out to get more share of the market or addressing the competitive issues that you see in the market place?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, I got it. No, we are not as you see historically been significantly subsidizing more expensive handsets. That does put pressure on us to get the best value for our customers with the most features. But the corollary to that is that we're subsi
componenttext: Okay. Well, I got it. No, we are not as you see historically been significantly subsidizing more expensive handsets. That does put pressure on us to get the best value for our customers with the most features. But the corollary to that is that we're subsidizing more heavily because we have more expensive handsets. And even though there may be some at the margin difference, there is not the significance of what I think you're attaching to it because we simply charge more.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: But I think we also need to go back to the understanding that since we charge now for the first month of service under WFA [Wireless for All], as mentioned in the prepared remarks, we have correspondingly reduced the handset prices. So the net-net out of
componenttext: But I think we also need to go back to the understanding that since we charge now for the first month of service under WFA [Wireless for All], as mentioned in the prepared remarks, we have correspondingly reduced the handset prices. So the net-net out of the store is the same to the consumer, but the appearance of a subsidy could appear bigger.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of David Barden with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of David Barden with Bank of America.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just want to talk about the data strategy a little bit. You guys are kind of talking about a move to web browsing, and smartphones, and such. But you guys made a choice not to do Rev. A. So the experience for users, if this does turn out to be the decis
componenttext: I just want to talk about the data strategy a little bit. You guys are kind of talking about a move to web browsing, and smartphones, and such. But you guys made a choice not to do Rev. A. So the experience for users, if this does turn out to be the decision-making tangent point as we get into the higher volume quarters at the end of the year, despite your device lineup, might put you at a disadvantage. I'd like to hear what your comfort level is and how you manage that relative to your competition out there? And then on the other half of it if you kind of move to LTE, if you can kind of elaborate a little bit more on where we go from Dallas/Fort Worth and Vegas? What are you planning on charging for the Craft? And if your base doesn't understand the difference in your data relative to competitors today, how do you make them understand the difference in your data strategy after you put LTE to work?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, let me take the last one first. We better have a more accomplished promotion and advertising and marketing staff to communicate to our customers  that a 4G phone is different than a 3G phone or a 2.5G phone. So we've got to be challenged there but i
componenttext: Well, let me take the last one first. We better have a more accomplished promotion and advertising and marketing staff to communicate to our customers  that a 4G phone is different than a 3G phone or a 2.5G phone. So we've got to be challenged there but it is a job. We won't just assume that our customers are going to know that. Let me go to the point that you made, I think, initially that the service that we have on the 1xRTT network, which we have today, and yes, we've avoided going to 3G Rev. A. We think it's too little, too late, and 4G is where the opportunity lies. The small screen and our willingness and, I think, focus on the Phone business as opposed to the Card or Dongle business kept us within, I think, our space and our capability. The disadvantage is on video streaming. And we have worked on the, shall we say, in the optimization area for our network to provide a good experience on our smartphones for streaming video over YouTube. There will be other sites that will be accessible. So we're working on the compression and the, shall we say, the network side to provide a better experience. But for just web browsing and the like, side-by-side comparisons do not show great differences. It's full-track downloads and streaming video where we have the differentials. And to the extent we can work on specific sites like YouTube, that, I think, we can get a reasonable parity until we have a much stronger offering in our 4G LTE network, which obviously does away with all those limitations.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: And could you follow up a little on what that LTE build plan is and kind of what the cost is going to be for the users that are having the 2G experience today?
componenttext: And could you follow up a little on what that LTE build plan is and kind of what the cost is going to be for the users that are having the 2G experience today?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're really not ready to release that information. But we are obviously focused on the two markets that we talked about. We are in friendly trial testing. So we'll have more on that, but we have not or not prepared to release further information on
componenttext: Well, we're really not ready to release that information. But we are obviously focused on the two markets that we talked about. We are in friendly trial testing. So we'll have more on that, but we have not or not prepared to release further information on this at this point.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Do you feel like the pricing that you're going to be able to bring to this device and to justify the build cost is going to be still within the affordability realm of your target market base?
componenttext: Do you feel like the pricing that you're going to be able to bring to this device and to justify the build cost is going to be still within the affordability realm of your target market base?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, we are not expecting to put a price umbrella on this. By the same token, we do see it as a premium service and thereby, we'll do accordingly. I think there may be a misconception on the 4G-LTE purpose, and I want to make it very clear. The purpos
componenttext: Yes. No, we are not expecting to put a price umbrella on this. By the same token, we do see it as a premium service and thereby, we'll do accordingly. I think there may be a misconception on the 4G-LTE purpose, and I want to make it very clear. The purpose is nothing short of a transformation of a network. This is just not getting something fast. This is getting what we think is the network of the future because we want to see this as being all-inclusive and we're working our way out of CDMA. But there's tremendous economies, we believe, and capacity for broadband data is so extremely strong, and the cost per byte is so very attractive. But this is nothing less, it's just not an overlay. This is a transformation of the entire network and that's the way we're viewing this.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: David, let me just address the handset piece. We're working with multiple OEMs today, and we're going to look at retail prices that are going to mirror where you would find some of our smartphone offerings today. We don't believe we're going to put our cu
componenttext: David, let me just address the handset piece. We're working with multiple OEMs today, and we're going to look at retail prices that are going to mirror where you would find some of our smartphone offerings today. We don't believe we're going to put our customers at a distinct disadvantage as they look to upgrade their phones if they're existing, or if they're new, wanting to come into the MetroPCS family. We think it's going to be extremely compelling. And remember, all of it's going to be under the no-contract umbrella. That's not available today, as Roger mentioned earlier. This is a transformation of our entire company to this network. But the handset choices will be robust. It'll take a little bit of time into 2011, but we've done a lot of work in this significant opportunity for us.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our final question comes from the line of Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our final question comes from the line of Simon Flannery with Morgan Stanley.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple for Braxton. I think, Braxton, you mentioned as the LTE rollout completes, that that's going to have a significant impact on your capital spending. Can you just give us some sense of what we should be thinking about in terms of sustainable CapEx
componenttext: A couple for Braxton. I think, Braxton, you mentioned as the LTE rollout completes, that that's going to have a significant impact on your capital spending. Can you just give us some sense of what we should be thinking about in terms of sustainable CapEx or sort of maintenance CapEx over the next couple of years? Is that sort of a low teens-type number of revenues? And then, I think, you touched on NOLs for a second. Can you just update us on when you expect those to expire, and cash tax payment, and so forth?

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, let me take the last one first quickly. As we said in the last quarter call that we currently expect to have adequate NOL to keep us from paying any meaningful federal taxes through early 2014. There'll be some minor state taxes that we pay pri
componenttext: Sure. Yes, let me take the last one first quickly. As we said in the last quarter call that we currently expect to have adequate NOL to keep us from paying any meaningful federal taxes through early 2014. There'll be some minor state taxes that we pay prior to 2014, but we don't really become a significant cash taxpayer until 2014. The second question, I think it's helpful to look at the previous guidance that we included in our 10-Q on CapEx, which for 2010, is $600 million to $800 million, of which, we commented that roughly half of it relates to LTE. When you really look at the dynamics of what's going on in 2010, we're certainly expanding networks and making our markets more relevant as we will continue to do in the future. But once you really get pass in the LTE spend and rationalization, probably more steady course without major market builds, is really roughly what we're spending in 2010, minus the LTE. Now I do want to say, there will be some LTE spend in 2011 as we continue to fully deploy LTE in all of our networks. So you shouldn't expect a 50% drop off next year. But the neat thing about LTE is it has tremendous scaling aspects unlike our CDMA CapEx. And that's not only from a CapEx standpoint, it's from an OpEx standpoint. The LTE overlay that we're deploying on our CDMA network, basically has the ability to scale without adding additional carriers like you do in the CDMA world, which means you really have more of a step-function increase in your CapEx and then you get tremendous CapEx scale after the initial deployment. And the same is true with the way that we're deploying backhaul. Roger, would you like to touch base on that a little because this is such an important point.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, there's two major elements, obviously. One is that we've now are deep into the exploration and gaining contracts with specific entities and as, I think, most of you are well aware, the cost per megabit as you increase the speeds are pretty sign
componenttext: Yes. Well, there's two major elements, obviously. One is that we've now are deep into the exploration and gaining contracts with specific entities and as, I think, most of you are well aware, the cost per megabit as you increase the speeds are pretty significantly reduced. So there's a tremendous difference in going from say 10 bits to 20, as it is from zero to five. And so there's a tremendous scaling opportunity in that sense. Obviously, there are many, many providers and this is becoming a very competitive front, a very important one, and that's one dimension of it. The other dimension of it is that with stack boxes [ph] in all our base stations that we have, LTE and CDMA, and by the way, the build is in place. So we're using all the facilities of our existing infrastructure, while we're adding these, let's call it, innovees [ph], to give us the LTE capability, is the fact that we're going to be overlaying our traffic on CDMA in the LTE network. So as we scale up in terms of users and capacity, that we get the benefit of both CDMA traffic and LTE. So I think combining it gives us scale out-of-the-box and as we get more scale, the price elasticity, or if you will, the cost to us elasticity, is very, very high. So higher volumes of data rate are at on a per bit basis much lower.

headline: MetroPCS Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Aug 05, 2010
componenttextpreview: At this time, I would turn the conference back over to Mr. Carter for closing remarks.
componenttext: At this time, I would turn the conference back over to Mr. Carter for closing remarks.
